The first, and most obvious things I noticed are that your distance from your brows to your eyes is totally different, and your jawlines and cheeks are as well. Very curious how likely it is for someone with a much more similar to one's own face doppelganger to exist. I've seen other content with people who have much, much more similar looking features, and while people's perception was kind of a mixed bag in that sometimes the majority rated the pair as being very identical and the computer generated sculpts also had their facial similarities as being very high, other times people rated the two "doppelgangers" as being extremely similar when their actual similarity was quite low compared to other couples. Needless to say, the topic of how people perceive faces is really interesting to say the least. My grandmother, spouse, and mom all think I look quite a lot like Scarlett Johansson, and for me I definitely don't see it. There's a lot of differences in proportions and features, that to me that's like saying Ann Hathaway looks a lot like her...and I don't think anyone would agree to that, they'd probably be like "No way, they look totally different!"...but idk, I often find it amazing how so many people find that people "look similar" who look nothing alike to me.

I apparently had two doppelgängers living in the same town as me about 30 years ago. The mailman at my apartment complex thought I was another resident of the complex, claiming we looked EXACTLY alike. He handed me the other guy’s mail one day when I went out to the mailboxes, and I told him I wasn’t that person. Another time, he asked me if I had forgotten something when I went to get my mail, because he said I had just been out there a few minutes ago. I kept a lookout for a guy who looked like me around the complex (it was several hundred apartments spread out over multiple buildings so he could easily have lived in a different building) but I never saw anyone who looked even vaguely like me.

The other doppelgänger — maybe the same guy, who knows? — was seen several times by a co-worker. She came in one day and was mad at me for having pretended not to know her the evening before. She had been out walking a hike & bike trail and she said she saw me jogging. When she called my name and said hello, the guy acted like he didn’t know her. Which he didn’t. It wasn’t me. She didn’t believe me when I told her I wasn’t out jogging the night before. She swore the guy looked EXACTLY like me. There were only five of us in our office and I saw her all day,naive days a week — we were all in the same room of the building — so she knew what I looked like. The only way I could prove it wasn’t me was to show her that I didn’t have a big eagle tattooed on my chest; the other guy did. The other guy also didn’t have much chest hair, while I was (and still am) completely covered in it. I was in my mid-20s back then and she was close to 60, so maybe she just thought all young guys with beards look alike...

Then in half a second they both realized that I wasn't her and the other guy glanced over at the ex to see his reaction.  They both stammeringly explained why they had reacted to my face so strongly.  They said that she was a very attractive lady but that they were absolutely not expecting to see her as she was on the other side of the country.  I smiled and said, "That must have been a shock to you!"  As soon as I spoke, you could see in their faces the resemblance dissolving, as my apparent differences in speech, accent and attitude made it immediately obvious that I was a completely different person.  The whole encounter took less than a minute as they came out of the elevator and I walked in.
